awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Deformation Behavior of Alumina-Forming Austenitic Stainless Steels
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Even with the increasing use of renewable energy, the primary energy sources for the foreseeable future for power generation are likely to be fossil fuels. Thus, for economic reasons, it is critical to use these resources as efficiently as possible. Increasing a power plant's operating temperature increases its efficiency. The limiting factor for higher temperature is materials that can operate at higher temperatures, and are economically viable. The aim of this project is to elucidate the deformation mechanisms in alumina-forming austenitic (AFA) stainless steels that are being considered for this application. The work will train both a Ph.D. student and several undergraduates in state of the art techniques.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The project will ascertain the deformation mechanisms associated with grain boundary (GB) precipitation strengthening, and attempt to understand the fundamental deformation behavior in alloys containing both a precipitate free zone (PFZ) and multiple types of precipitates in both the GBs and the matrix each of which can contribute differently to the deformation behavior. The work will be performed on the model AFA stainless steel Fe-20Cr-30Ni-2Nb-5Al. Detailed microstructural and defect characterization by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) wlll be performed before and after mechanical testing. TEM in-situ straining and SEM in-situ straining studies performed at both room temperature and 750C will examine both dislocation/precipitate and dislocation/GB interactions, including understanding the role of the PFZ along the GBs. The work will train both a Ph.D. student and several undergraduates in state of the art techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Even with the surge in use of renewable energy, for the foreseeable future the primary energy source for power applications is likely to be fossil fuels, particularly with the low price of natural gas. Using these resources as efficiently as possible for both economic reasons and to minimize carbon dioxide emissions is critical. In order for power plants to be more efficient they need to run at higher temperature: an operating temperature increase from 600oC to 750oC would increase the efficiency from <40% to >50%, and reduce CO2 emissions by 40-50%.  This requires materials that are strong enough, can withstand an environment that may contain impurities in addition to steam, display good oxidation and corrosion resistance and are economically viable. The Department of Energy-defined goal for alloys for the next-generation Advanced Ultra Supercritical (AUSC) steam plants is 35 MPa at 750oC, which are the conditions that we focussed on in this proposal. Affordable materials that can satisfy these requirements will also likely find use in supercritical CO2 cycles and in tubing for concentrated thermal solar power.

The steels that are currently used in power plants are limited to operating temperatures less than 600oC. Nickel-based superalloys, some titanium alloys, and, possibly, oxide-dispersion strengthened steels can satisfy the strength and, at least for nickel-based alloys, the oxidation and corrosion requirements at elevated temperatures.  Unfortunately, these materials are too expensive except for use in specialized applications. This critical need for advanced materials for steam turbine components in ultra supercritical power plants has been long recognized and is the basis of efforts in Japan, Europe, China, India and the U.S. Recent efforts in this area have focused on devising new alumina-forming austenitic stainless steels (AFA steels) strengthened with Laves phases.

The aim of this project was to understand the fundamental deformation of a model AFA stainless steel Fe-20Cr-30Ni-2Nb-5Al, which was chosen because it has good mechanical properties at high temperature and good oxidation resistance. The work involved creep testing, and detailed microstructural and defect characterization using transmission electron microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. A particular goal was to understand how the three different precipitates present contributed to the strength and how the precipitate free zone along the grain boundaries (GBs) affected the mechanical properties.

 Our key observations are:

1. Unlike in previous studies by others, we found a correlation between the creep rate and yield strength at 760oC of heat treated Fe-20Cr-30Ni-2Nb-5Al was observed with specimens containing the finest initial Laves phase and NiAl particle size showing the highest yield strength and smallest creep strain, i.e. the high temperature strength and creep rate of Fe-20Cr-30Ni-2Nb-5Al is highly dependent on the size, spacing, and location of the precipitates.

2. As the microstructure evolves continuously during creep, a true steady-state creep rate is never reached.

3. All precipitates in the matrix follow the Ostwald ripening law for coarsening during creep.

4. The GB percent coverage with precipitates and the width of the GB precipitates increase during creep.

5. A precipitate-free zone (PFZ) forms during creep due to solute depletion near the GBs and large matrix precipitates. The PFZ growth is controlled by the diffusion of atoms through the matrix.

6. Nano-sized L12 precipitates provide significant strengthening in the matrix and can be modeled well using a threshold stress term in the power law creep equation. GBs are strengthened by coverage with Laves phase and B2 precipitates. These precipitates act both as obstacles to dislocation motion and reduce GB sliding. The alloy ultimately fails with an intergranular fracture mode at elevated temperatures, indicating that the coarse GB precipitates or the PFZ are the weak point in the material.

7. The PFZ is softer than the L12-strengthened matrix. Micro-cracks are observed in the PFZ from crept samples stopped prior to failure, indicating that fracture may initiate in the PFZ during creep and that the PFZ ultimately compromises the creep strength.

8. While machine learning models showed promise for improving the efficiency of alloy design, current models need to be improved by: incorporating information on size and spacing of precipitates, improving the dataset by representing the full range of alloys (i.e. "bad" alloys also need to be tested), and a creep strength metric needs to be implemented in order to compare tests performed at different conditions.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2021
Modified by: Ian Baker
